I agree with Fish’s argument that the constant use and dependency on technology has caused some negative effects. He states that today’s youth has more preference for texting each other rather than making a phone call or having a physical encounter. It seems that today, people have become so reliant on technology that the idea of physically communicating with people has become somewhat fearful. In teaching, technology has also had a detriment effect especially in testing. Due to the idea that determining the student’s ability is based on test score taken from standardized test, the idea of memorizing information and facts have become key to doing well. Instead of focusing on strategies for thinking critically or rhetorically so that students will gain knowledge, wisdom and insight, teachers are more worried about having their students learn what is required to pass these state-wide test.

Bob, most loans have an interest rate of libor *PLUS* a certain fixed amount.
For example, millions of college students with student loans and municipalities across the US paid lower interest rates thanks to these guys.
Why is no one writing about that?

Yes. In fact we all suffer from this fraud. Interest rate swaps depend on Libor. So for example, the MTA borrows money with an interest rate swap, which means that they pay a fixed rate, say 6% minus whatever the Libor rate is. So if the Libor rate is lowered they pay more. (6%-4%=2%, 6%-0.5%=5.5%). This work out well if the Libor rate is high, but the banks crashed the economy and rates have been very low and manipulating the rate even lower hurts even more.
The very low Libor rates is why the MTA is broke and has to raise fares all the time. This is happening all across the country. There are trillions of dollars dependent on interest rate swaps throughout the world. It is truly theft on a grand scale.

A bit rambling, Doug, which is unlike you.

While the fuzzy inefficiency of large MSM publications is a valid point to make, it remains that all society suffers when bureaus are not maintained globally and not properly staffed. While efforts should be made to lessen the fuzziness and tighten operations, its not so much the central operational model but the distribution model and the grotesque expense related to it that need to change.

Bezos bought the WashPost, I'm convinced, to take it online entirely, preparing to cater to a world where everyone who once folded a newspaper now sports an iPad. As a model his success would evangelize, it will do wonders for the bottom line, flexibility and growth potential for what become content generators, aggregators and analyzers, and weigh stations for distinctive opinion -- but shorn of this immense and almost obsolete print engine that fixes that content immutably in every edition.

This says nothing useful about church-state walls, but, then ... neither did you.

One of the major problems in American media, especially traditional print publications, is not that they are not viable, it is that they are not viable in the way Wall Street wants them to be. Wall Street is making money by driving stocks down, shorting them. When the Washington Post was sold not long ago, its publisher, in a little noticed aside, said the paper would be "cash flow positive" for at least a few years. Profits, in other words. That's not, of course, what Wall Street wants. It wants either rapidly growing companies or those that are failing, or appearing to fail, so that it can make money by pulling support out from under them.

For the better part of ten years, print has been talked down, first, by reporters and editors who ran "woe is me" stories by the hundreds as layoffs hit newspapers, and next by Wall Street, ready to feast on the fading. Did anyone stop to think that it was never written in God's own tablets that every major newspaper was supposed to have hundreds and hundreds of editorial employees, bureaus around the world, Washington bureaus and to spend endlessly sending reporters almost anywhere they wanted to go? Some senior reporters at major publications seemed to be on virtual scholarships.

The wall between church and state was a fiction, but a useful one. People need to believe in independence and fight for it. The new era presents challenges on all sides, but fighting over what's lost detracts from facing the future.

Everyone should take a basic level environmental science course! We cannot continue to open more lands to agriculture without long term effects. Agriculture, especially as it is practiced now, leads to soil degradation and lack of biodiversity. The more land cleared for agriculture, the more land is vulnerable to becoming a wasteland. Trees, which hold water and reduce flooding are cleared. Land that once held numerous species is reduced to one single type of crop planting. Animals, insects etc. that depended on the diversity of flora to procreate, hibernate, migrate are closed out and threatened, etc. In other words, using land to grow crops leads to inherent problems, if other than on an extremely small scale. Even with the most sustainable practices, agriculture is a practice that causes disruption and fragility of ecological systems. Farming is inherently risky as regards to biological cycles.

As regards to fishing, please look into projections for losses of global fish populations. The most threatened species are fish and birds. We are projected to lose roughly 50 percent of their species in the near future. As it is now, fish populations are teetering on the edge of constantly being fished near capacity. Their are efforts to control this, but they are constantly undermined by monetary interests and are too conservative in re-population estimates.
